;;“这是一笔不错的交易，”舍弗勒首席执行官克劳斯·罗森菲尔德 (Klaus Rosenfeld) 笑道是一家位于巴伐利亚黑措根奥拉赫的汽车零部件制造商。 10 月 9 日凌晨，他打电话给巴伐利亚竞争对手维特斯科 (Vitesco) 的同行安德烈亚斯·沃尔夫 (Andreas Wolf)，提出收购舍弗勒尚未拥有的公司 50.1% 的股份。罗森菲尔德表示，这笔 36 亿欧元（合 38 亿美元）的交易将在正在向电动汽车转型的行业中打造出一家具有竞争力的德国巨头。

;
;;
;

;舍弗勒上次尝试大规模收购是在 2008 年，当时它赢得了控股权大陆航空的规模是其规模的三倍。这笔完全由债务融资的交易几乎让这个家族企业破产。这次交易规模较小——Vitesco 本身于 2021 年从大陆集团分拆出来，年销售额为 90 亿欧元，而舍弗勒的年销售额为 160 亿欧元。此次合并也减少了对借钱的依赖。罗森菲尔德先生于 2014 年成为舍弗勒的老板，一年后让公司上市，他是一位受过训练的银行家，性情谨慎。

;

;此次收购预计每年将节省约 5 亿欧元的成本。它还将简化舍弗勒的股东结构，提高透明度，并使舍弗勒股票更容易交易。作为交易的一部分，舍弗勒家族同意放弃对投票权股份的垄断（尽管它将继续牢牢控制，持有新公司 75% 的股份）。最重要的是，此次交易将打造一家全球汽车零部件巨头，在全球拥有 12 万名员工。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;为了在电动汽车时代蓬勃发展（;EV ;s)，汽车零部件行业需要整合。电动汽车所需的零部件比配备内燃机 (;ICE;) 的汽车少得多，因此规模经济更加重要。德国华宝银行的 Marc-René Tonn 表示，这笔交易肯定会巩固舍弗勒在电动汽车业务中的地位。维特斯科 (Vitesco) 是;电动汽车;电动马达和电子产品的大型供应商。 2022 年，该公司收到了超过 100 亿欧元的此类 ;EV; 零部件订单，是舍弗勒的两倍，预计今年也将达到类似数量。

;

;合并后的公司仍然面临着挑战。尽管与电动汽车相关的订单不断增加，但动力总成和底盘等与内燃机相关的零部件约占舍弗勒年销售额的 40% 和纬创的 80%。两家公司都严重依赖中国。舍弗勒在中国拥有13,000名员工和13家工厂。广阔的中国市场也占其销售额的23%。 Vitesco 在中国有四家工厂，拥有约 6,500 名员工，其收入的 15% 来自中国。

;

;罗森菲尔德先生认为，在中西方关系日益紧张之际，与中国的关系绝非一种地缘政治负担，而是一种商业资产。他表示，这笔交易“将有助于我们的中国业务”。这些不仅仅涉及汽车零部件；舍弗勒的中国工厂还生产飞机和风力涡轮机的轴承系统。此外，与中国汽车制造商的良好关系也很重要，还有另一个原因。当中国雄心勃勃的电动汽车制造商在欧洲设厂时，他们将需要当地供应商。舍弗勒看起来很适合成为其中之一。 ;■;

; Sat, 14 Oct 2023 02:57:02 +0800 Hamas’s attack was the bloodiest in Israel’s history | Briefinghttps://www.economist.com/briefing/2023/10/12/hamass-attack-was-the-bloodiest-in-israels-history ;

;;我;;以色列人知道;他们不能认为自己的人身安全是理所当然的。但这个国家 75 年的历史无法让他们为 10 月 7 日的大屠杀做好准备。截至《经济学人》发稿时估计，在哈马斯袭击中丧生的以色列人人数已达到 1,300 人，另有 3,300 人受伤。据信大约有 150 名人质被劫持到加沙。

;
;;
;

;以色列情报部门未能预见到这次袭击，相当于袭击的开始。 1973 年的赎罪日战争，埃及和叙利亚在犹太教最重要的节日同时发动突然袭击。然而，平民丧生的人数却截然不同。 1973 年，那些入侵军队寻求的是夺取领土，而不是屠杀非战斗人员。在为期三周的战争中死亡的 2,656 名以色列人都是士兵。相比之下，本周哈马斯受害者中只有约 13% 是现役军人。

;;

;大多数受害者是被直播的枪手射杀的越过边境，最远到达以色列境内约 25 公里（15 英里）的一座城市奥法基姆 (Ofakim)。据目前估计，最致命的袭击发生在距边境约 5 公里的基布兹雷姆附近的沙漠中的一个音乐节上，至少有 260 人被谋杀。

;;
;
;

;然而内塔尼亚胡先生始终将自己的政治生存置于首位。即使在战争期间，他似乎仍在继续这样做，拒绝将极右翼政党踢出政府。本-格维尔先生仍然有能力在危险时刻制造麻烦。他仍然负责警察工作，并在最近几天加剧了与以色列阿拉伯人口的紧张关系。内塔尼亚胡先生不愿意背弃极右翼伙伴，因为如果他想在战后继续掌权并希望赢得另一次选举，他就需要他们的支持。支持内塔尼亚胡的媒体代理人辩称，内塔尼亚胡不能将财政部长兼极右宗教犹太复国主义党领袖贝扎莱尔·斯莫特里奇边缘化，因为斯莫特里奇的一些选民现在正在前线奋战。

;

;反对派领导人寻求组建联合政府，因为他们渴望抵消极右翼的影响，并为政府注入一些专业精神和经验。但他们也知道，加入内阁让内塔尼亚胡有机会摆脱导致以色列卷入这场战争的失败的部分责任。他们坚信，当清算到来时，他会抓住它。此外，他们担心自己在政府中的存在将使受污染的总理及其激进联盟合法化。以色列最终可能会进行政治重组，增加中间派政党的权重，减少极端主义政党的权重。但可能只有在内塔尼亚胡先生离开舞台之后。

;

;他是以色列任期最长的总理，但无论他在漫长的公共生涯中为以色列取得了哪些成就，他的遗产将永远被以下事实所掩盖：在他任内发生了可怕的事件。他是战略概念的首席设计师，该概念的理念是，哈马斯在加沙构成的威胁可以通过建立高科技边境屏障来应对，而不是寻求长期解决方案和改善加沙的条件。这个想法在 10 月 7 日惨遭失败。

;

;历届总理都曾面临过军事失败。在每一个案例中——1973年赎罪日战争后的果尔达·梅厄、1982年黎巴嫩战争后的梅纳赫姆·贝京和2006年黎巴嫩战争后的埃胡德·奥尔默特——他们都在战争结束后两年内宣布辞职。当这场战争结束后，公众的愤怒浪潮席卷而来时，内塔尼亚胡先生可能会面临同样的命运。政治生涯结束的前景似乎几乎不可避免地会影响他现在的决策，而他将拼命地坚持下去。这使得那些加入他内阁的人试图迫使他关注国家安全而不是他的政治生存变得更加紧迫。 ;■;

; Fri, 13 Oct 2023 14:27:07 +0800 American and Chinese scientists are decoupling, too | Science & technologyhttps://www.economist.com/science-and-technology/2023/10/11/american-and-chinese-scientists-are-decoupling-too ;
;< /div>;

;;T;;这里;有很多衡量中国崛起的方法。它是世界第二大经济体、最大的制造商和最大的债权人。 2021 年，它又跨过了另一个里程碑。那一年，中国科学家发表的论文数量首次超过美国或欧盟同行（见图1）。改善的不仅仅是数量。 ;Nature; 索引由同名期刊出版商运营，追踪对世界上最受推崇的健康和自然科学期刊的贡献。 Chinese researchers rank first in the natural sciences, and second overall.

;
;;
;

;Cause for celebration, no doubt, in Beijing.但在华盛顿，这个消息可能不太受欢迎。美国对中国的崛起，尤其是其不断增长的科技实力越来越感到沮丧。在前共和党总统唐纳德·特朗普和现任民主党总统乔·拜登的领导下，中国实施了关税、规则和补贴，旨在阻碍中国高科技企业，同时促进自身发展。中国对此进行了报复，对一些美国大型科技公司采取了行动。二十年前，政治家们支持全球化和自由贸易。当前，“脱钩”、国家安全、“友邻”成为热门话题。

;

;Conscious uncoupling

;

;Academia is not immune.两国的新规则和冷淡的政治使研究人员的合作变得更加困难。 8 月，美国同意将 1979 年签署的一项具有里程碑意义的科学合作协议临时延长六个月。几位美国政界人士希望完全废除该协议，他们在一封公开信中声称，通过与中国研究人员合作，美国正在“推动它自己的毁灭。”

;
;;

;The strains can be seen in the figures. 2020年，美国和中国研究人员共同撰写的论文数量首次下降。第二年，这是可获得的最新数据，该数字再次下降，尽管英国等其他一些国家的数字仍在上升。美国向中国学生和学者发放的签证数量也有所下降，降至 2015 年峰值的三分之一左右（见图 2）。 Scientifically as well as politically, the countries are drawing apart.

;

;The Science and Technology Agreement, as the 1979 pact is called, was the first bilateral treaty signed between America and China after they re-established diplomatic relations.几项具有里程碑意义的研究都属于它的范畴。 1983 年开始的一个长期项目跟踪了 285,000 名中国女性，帮助证明叶酸可以预防脊柱裂（一种罕见的先天缺陷）。如今，面粉、面包、麦片和其他主食中都添加了叶酸。鼓励孕妇多服用。流感研究方面的合作有助于预测每年哪些流感病毒株可能占主导地位，从而改进疫苗。

;

;Even superpower rivals can agree that medical research is a good thing. But China's advances in other areas of science, such as computing, materials science and ;AI;, have made American policymakers uneasy.批评者认为，中国的科学受益于美国的学术透明度和专业知识，但中国并不总是回报这种恩惠。 Doubters also point to China's policy of “civil-military fusion”, in which the fruits of civilian research are scrutinised for any useful military applications.

;

;China retorts that America's worries about national security have led to the unfair targeting of Chinese researchers at American universities.经常受到投诉的目标之一是司法部的“中国倡议”，该倡议于 2018 年至 2022 年期间启动，旨在调查涉嫌中国技术间谍活动的案件。但实际案例似乎很少。该倡议调查了至少 150 名华裔学者，但仅对少数人定罪。有些是针对较轻的罪行，例如拨款欺诈。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;;

;Some of the investigations have become very public fiascos, as with the case of Gang Chen, a well regarded mechanical engineer of Chinese origin who is now at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.陈博士于 2021 年被捕。在对他的所有指控被撤销之前，他休了一年学术假。其他研究人员被所在大学解雇，并发现自己被列入禁飞名单。学者们表示，这一举措引发了怀疑和不信任的气氛。

;

;China, meanwhile, has national-security concerns of its own, which can likewise impede co-operation.近年来出台的规则几乎禁止导出许多不同类型的数据。例如，官员已禁止非中国实体收集基因组数据。如果没有政府里的朋友，外国社会科学研究人员很少能获得经济和社会调查的机会。 The rules are vague, leaving even researchers keen to work with colleagues overseas unsure what they are allowed to share.

;

;A cooling of ties will make life harder for both sides.中国学者会发现在美国大学获得经验更加困难，而美国大学在几乎每个学科的世界排名中仍然占据主导地位。由于中国现在本身就是一个科学强国，在多个领域拥有尖端研究人员，美国科学也将受到影响。

;

;The benefits of collaboration are “significant,” and benefit American institutions slightly more than Chinese ones, says Jonathan Adams, who tracks academic information at Clarivate, a data provider. A study published in 2020 by Jenny Lee and John Haupt at the University of Arizona, found that, when papers co-written with Chinese scientists were excluded, the number of American publications in science and engineering fell slightly between 2014 and 2018.

;
;

;Give me your brainy masses

;

;America's scientific pre-eminence has been built at least partly on its ability to attract the world's best.疫情爆发前，美国大学科学、技术、工程和数学专业的研究生中约有 16% 是中国人。今天的研究生往往会成为明天的教授。和陈博士一样，许多中国学生在完成学业后选择留在美国。美国领导人应该热衷于鼓励这一点。 ;■;

;

; Fri, 13 Oct 2023 07:27:02 +0800 The rise of Britain’s new nanny state | Britainhttps://www.economist.com/britain/2023/10/10/the-rise-of-britains-new-nanny-state ;
;
;

;;N;;othing annoys; a certain type of Briton more than the government standing between him and a painful death. The phrase “nanny state” first appeared with the introduction of a 70mph speed limit on England's motorways in 1965. Iain Macleod, a former Conservative minister who invented the term, lampooned the transport minister responsible in the ;Spectator;: “Why doesn't he follow his own logic and…go back to where we started with a 5mph limit and the man with the red flag?”

;

;Macleod would not have enjoyed this year's ;party-conference season;. Nanny has been busy. The Conservative government plans to make it illegal for anyone born after 2009 to buy tobacco, in a policy proposed on an apparent whim by Rishi Sunak, the increasingly presidential prime minister. There is no opposition. “It's a good ;New Zealand; Labour policy, which I was planning to steal,” says Wes Streeting, Labour's shadow health secretary.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Nor did nanny stop there. Labour wants three- to five-year-olds to have tooth-brushing lessons. Under a Labour government, a crackdown on vaping is coming, with bans on some flavours and rules on advertising likely. Although a proposed ;junk-food advertising ban; has been pushed back by the Tories, it will be enthusiastically approved by a future Labour government. Outside Westminster, people want to go further. Sir Tony Blair's well-funded think-tank, which has the ear of Labour's leaders, lobbies loud and hard for a tax on junk food itself. In a political pincer movement, so does George Osborne, a former Conservative chancellor.

;

;What has changed since Macleod's day is that politicians now see the nanny state as a necessity, rather than a nice-to-have. The old nanny state was paternalistic, protecting people from themselves. In the new nanny state, policy is aimed at protecting the state from the people.

;

;Cigarettes are to be banned because smokers heap pressure on the ;nhs;, says Mr Sunak. Toddler teeth must be brushed because tooth decay can land children in hospital, which costs taxpayers money, says Mr Streeting. “You can't run a modern health-care system where people are going to live much longer unless they take some responsibility,” says Sir Tony. This is a mentality best exemplified by a sign spotted in Devon: “Cyclists. Exton Village. NOT Racetrack. For ;nhs; sake. Slow down!”

;

;For politicians, the new nanny state still retains all its old attractions. Governing is often hard. Railways come in late and over budget; pandemics and wars disrupt plans. In contrast, banning things is easy. A single piece of legislation can sweep a product from shelves or whack up the price of an unhealthy snack. It is also cheap. Neither party has much fiscal leeway. A policy with a low price tag is a valuable thing.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;And whereas most politicians have to watch as successors unpick their hard work, bans are rarely undone. New Labour's public smoking ban was controversial when it was introduced in 2007. Sir Tony fretted that working-class voters would desert the party (he waited until he was almost out of office to introduce it). Although some ;MP;s worried, the majority of voters supported it from the off. Banning cigarettes means Mr Sunak will have at least one lasting policy from his (probably brief) tenure.

;

;This intoxicating mix of ease, price and instant legacy means even libertine politicians become statist in power. For years ;Boris Johnson;, a former editor of the ;Spectator;, took aim at the fusspot nature of New Labour. It was the inalienable right of an Englishman to stuff his face with chocolate, crisps and cheese if he so chose. “Face it: it's all your own fat fault”, ran one of his columns in 2004. But once in power, it was Mr Johnson who pushed an anti-obesity scheme that would ban daytime advertising of junk food. Outside a few columnists and the occasional Tory ;mp;, there are few libertarians in British politics.

;

;Intrusion in one area can lead to intrusion elsewhere. Despite the wishes of Sir Tony and many public-health academics, neither party will touch junk-food taxes while inflation remains high. Whether that will hold once inflation is tamed is another matter. Steep taxes on unhealthy food appear reasonable when compared with, say, straight prohibition of tobacco. And although few lobby for an outright ban on certain foods now, not many were pushing for a ban on cigarette sales until recently.

;

;A spoonful of sugar? Help the waiting list go down!

;

;Expectations of the state have increased dramatically since 2020. It is not enough for it to fend off invaders and protect personal property. Nor is the post-war welfare state, with health care and welfare on tap, sufficient. Both parties now pledge comprehensive free child care. Each promises to protect elderly voters from the cost of social care. Voters benefited from gigantic energy subsidies when gas prices shot up in 2022. Theresa May, a former prime minister, once complained that voters think their own rainy-day funds must not be touched, even on rainy days. Whatever the problem, she despaired, voters now expect the state to step in.

;

;Politicians are quietly turning this expectation into a quid pro quo: if voters want more from the state, the state will want more from voters. People have to pay more for public services, for one thing. Taxes have risen, and will keep rising as long as people's demands increase. The Conservatives have managed this stealthily, by letting inflation push people into higher tax brackets. This alone will bring in about £40bn ($49bn; 2% of ;GDP;) annually by the end of the decade—enough to build a leg of ;hs;2 each year.

;

;But it also means the state will intrude more into the lives of voters, in a bid to keep a lid on the cost of the services they demand. Compared with lockdowns, even sweeping measures seem small bore. Banning cigarettes seems less invasive than when the government briefly made it illegal to meet friends in your garden, all in the name of keeping the ;nhs; running. That principle is now the norm. In the new nanny state, everyone is a public servant. ;■;

;
